bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George P. Berry, November 19, 1952

div1.p: Hench inquires whether the Medical School of Harvard University might wish to have a representative place a wreath under the medallion of Wood during the dedication ceremonies of Camp Lazear. Wood graduated from Harvard Medical School in the late 1880s.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George P. Berry, November 19, 1952
div1.opener:
November 19, 1952
Dr. George P. Berry
Dean of the Medical School
Harvard University
Boston, Massachusetts
My dear Doctor Berry:
div1.p:
On December 3, the anniversary of the birthday of Carlos Finlay, which is
“Physicians' Day in Cuba,” the Cuban Government is memorializing the re-
mains of Walter Reed's Camp Lazear in Quemados de Marianao. The remains
of Building No. 1 have been repaired, a little park has been made and on
a stone wall will be unveiled several individual bronze medallions, pro-
files of Finlay, Delgado, Reed, Carroll, Lazear, Agramonte and Wood. On
each side will be a bronze tablet with the names of the volunteers who
served as guinea pigs.

This will be, I believe, a significant occasion because heretofore there
has been, unfortunately, a considerable feeling of animosity in certain
Cuban circles against those who have honored Reed and his colleagues,
the Cuban viewpoint being that American medicine has ignored the great
contribution of Finlay. Now for the first time the Cuban government is
honoring the contribution of the Americans by memorializing Camp Lazear
in this way. Although I am not certain, it is possible that they may
not retain the name Camp Lazear but may rename the place Parque Finlay.
Nevertheless the bronze tablets, the dedicatory speeches and so on, will
make clear the significance of this spot and they are making a small but
nevertheless fine beginning toward a better Cuban-American relationship.

I believe that the Cuban Government is planning to send invitations to a
number of Americans and American medical institutions. They have been
delayed in doing this because of some uncertainty as to the final date
for the dedication but the date has now been set for December 3. I know
that General Streit, Commanding General of Walter Reed General Hospital,
will be there, representing the Surgeon General and a few others are
planning to go. The U. S. Embassy will participate in the ceremonies.

It seems to me that the Americans who attend this ceremony should not go
empty-handed but should respond in a generous way to the gracious intent
of the Cuban Government and medical profession and thus strengthen the
friendship between the Cuban and American medical professions. It oc-
curred to me that since General Wood was a graduate of the Medical School
of Harvard University (1884, or was it 1883), the Medical School or the
Dr. George P. Berry
- 2 -
November 19, 1952
Medical Alumni Association might wish to have a representative of their
institution place a wreath or floral decoration under the medallion of
General Wood on this occasion. Therefore I am writing you asking whether
you would think that would be appropriate. I am writing similar letters
to the other half dozen institutions from which those who are mainly to
be honored obtained their medical degrees.

This is merely a request for information as to whether you would think this
gesture appropriate. If so, I shall communicate by cable with the Cuban
authorities and ask them if they will make a place during the ceremony
for the placing of these wreaths.

If you have an alumnus that lives in Havana (and it need not necessarily
be a physician) it would be most appropriate for him to place the wreath
at the proper time; or better yet, if one of your faculty could go (and
I fear that the Cuban Government has no monetary subsidy), that would be
excellent and I will request that a personal invitation be sent for them.
If neither of these are possible, I would myself see to it that the wreath
was placed at the proper time, either by the American Ambassador, by
General Streit or by myself. However it would be much more effective if
a representative of your institution could do that, providing this sug-
gestion is approved first by you and then by our Cuban hosts.

Our local florist has told me that he thought a circular wreath of laurel
leaves, perhaps 30 inches in diameter, would be appropriate, perhaps with
a silk ribbon either with the colors of the college or red, white and blue
for the United States, at a cost of perhaps $15 or so. Should you approve
of the general idea, would you care to have your own representative arrange
for the preparation of the wreath in Havana? If not, I should be glad to
help in any way and could either have the half dozen or so wreaths made
up in Havana a day or two ahead or, according to our local florist, they
can be made up in Miami and flown to Havana and delivered to the appropriate
person for placement.

I would greatly appreciate hearing from you at your earliest convenience.
Enclosed please find a photograph of the blue print and a reprint which
will refresh your mind on the significance of Camp Lazear.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosures
P.S.: If it seems more appropriate, you might prefer to send a telegraphic
message. The wire could be sent either to His Excellency Dr. Jose Andreu,
El Ministro de Salubridad y Asistencia Social or to one of his agents in
this matter, Dr. Pedro Nogueira, Marti 219, Marianao, Havana, or Dr. Cesar
Rodriguez Exposito, Secretary, Marti 219, Marianao, Havana.
